qas.question: What textile were some of the early Han maps made from?
In what type of building were silken maps found?
Which individual created the very first raised relief map?
What food stable was the first raised relief map created from?

context: Evidence found in Chinese literature, and archaeological evidence, show that cartography existed in China before the Han. Some of the earliest Han maps discovered were ink-penned <a0_0>silk<a0_0/> maps found amongst the Mawangdui Silk Texts in a 2nd-century-BC <a1_0>tomb<a1_0/>. The general <a2_0>Ma Yuan<a2_0/> created the world's first known raised-relief map from <a3_0>rice<a3_0/> in the 1st century AD. This date could be revised if the tomb of Qin Shi Huang is excavated and the account in the Records of the Grand Historian concerning a model map of the empire is proven to be true.
